docs.lead_paragraph: Rebecca Skloot (April 16) did a fine job pointing toward the biologically-complicated future facing us all. But only in a country like the United States, where health care has become so divorced from other fundamental civic responsibilities, could we have the situation where universities fight with their faculty, patients with their doctors and everyone with their insurance carriers. Contrast our muddle with Iceland, where an ambitious company, deCODE, persuaded the government to capture its entire population's genetic data and combine it with deep, longitudinal patient records. Such consistent record-keeping is an underappreciated benefit of nationalized health care. Richard K. Belew San Diego
docs.abstract: Richard K Belew letter comments on Rebecca Skloot's April 16 article on control of blood and tissue samples taken from Americans in medical tests and procedures
docs.snippet: Rebecca Skloot (April 16) did a fine job pointing toward the biologically-complicated future facing us all. But only in a country like the United States, where health care has become so divorced from other fundamental civic responsibilities, could we...

docs.lead_paragraph: This fall, for the third time since 9/11, American voters will choose between Democrats and Republicans while knowing what only one party believes about national security. In 2002, Democratic candidates tried to change the subject, focusing on Social Security and health care instead. In 2004, John Kerry substituted biography for ideology, largely ignoring his own extensive foreign-policy record and stressing his service in Vietnam. In this year's Senate and House races, the party looks set to reprise Michael Dukakis's old theme: competence. Rather than tell Americans what their vision is, Democrats will assure them that they can execute it better than George W. Bush.

headline.main: The Rehabilitation of the Cold-War Liberal

docs.abstract: Peter Beinart article urges liberals to look to Reinhold Niebuhr, George F Kennan and other cold-war liberals for alternative to conservative conception of America as the force for good in epic struggle against evil in post-9/11 world; says cold-war liberals knew that fight against Communism, like today's struggle against jihadist terrorism, is not just struggle for democracy, but also one for economic opportunity at home and abroad; says they also realized that an America too confident in its own righteousness could easily emulate its evil enemy and therefore argued that America had to submit to international restraints on its exercise of power; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Maybe what the Democrats need post-9/11 is exactly what they rejected after Vietnam.

docs.lead_paragraph: AT her dental appointments, Deann Romanick sips green tea and takes in the scent of lavender and the sounds of New Age music. She gets a free paraffin hand wax treatment, blankets, a warm neck pad and video eyeglasses in which she can watch ''Seinfeld'' episodes while the dentist works on her teeth. The pampering eased her through a root canal and a tooth replacement, and now, with her fear of dental work gone, she has moved on to more elective procedures. Ms. Romanick, 34, a graduate student from Germantown, Md., spent $399 for teeth whitening and next plans to straighten her teeth with removable plastic braces, which can cost up to $3,500.

headline.main: At the Dentist's Office, X-Rays, Root Canals And, Now, Pampering

docs.abstract: Article on growing number of dentists who are turning practices into 'dental spas' that offer variety of amenities; dentists hope perks such as fresh-baked cookies, overstuffed couches, body waxing, facials, massages and pedicures may result in more elective cosmetic dentistry and help patients see office visits as more routine; spa services go hand in hand with growth of cosmetic dentistry, which is not usually covered by dental insurance plans; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A growing number of dentists are turning their practices into "dental spas" that offer perks like fresh-baked cookies and pedicures.

docs.lead_paragraph: AS the only business columnist I know who was once a doorman, I couldn't read about the last-minute contract agreement for New York's apartment-building workers without thinking about the guillotine. It's not that my experience -- three summers at the portal of a classy old pile on 69th and Lexington -- turned me into a revolutionary. Quite the contrary, those summers gave me the wherewithal to grab a low spot on the totem pole of bourgeois life, a spot to which I have clung desperately ever since.

headline.main: What's Inequality? Ask a Former Doorman

docs.abstract: Daniel Akst On the Contrary column on widening wage differential among blue-collar workers, college graduates and chief executives in America and potential impact on American society; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: As the only business columnist I know who was once a doorman, the contract agreement for New York's apartment-building workers made me think about income inequality.

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S often argued that foreigners funnel their money into the United States because it is a great investment. But for many countries, plowing money into the United States these days is not all that compelling a deal. Poor nations are financing much of the United States' current account deficit. They are losing money in the process, and as the losses mount, they will be tempted to do something better with their cash.

headline.main: Are Poor Nations Wasting Their Money on Dollars?

docs.abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic View column explores question of whether poor nations are wasting their money by investing in US dollars; International Monetary Fund reports that international reserves held by developing countries doubled in three years, to $2.9 trillion at end of 2005, equivalent to almost one-third of their total gross domestic product, much of which is languishing at low rates of return in American government bonds; graph (M)
docs.snippet: Poor nations are financing much of the United States' current deficit, and they are losing money in the process.

docs.lead_paragraph: Vytra Health Plans Long Island, a health maintenance organization in Melville, has been fined $300,000 and ordered to pay $2.1 million in refunds or credits to policyholders who were overcharged from January 2003 to June 2005, Howard Mills, the New York State Superintendent of Insurance, said on Tuesday. An audit found that 53 companies on Long Island, each with 50 to 200 employees, were billed too much because the company used a formula for setting rates that the state had not approved. Some 574 individuals who bought coverage directly from Vytra were also overcharged.
docs.abstract: Vytra Health Plans Long Island is fined $300,000 and ordered to pay $2.1 million in refunds or credits to policyholders overcharged from January 2003 to June 2005 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Genzyme won federal approval yesterday to sell the first drug for Pompe disease, a rare inherited enzyme deficiency that destroys muscles and can kill infants by their first birthday. The drug, Myozyme, is the fourth developed by Genzyme to treat a rare enzyme deficiency under the incentives provided by the federal government to develop medicines for so-called orphan diseases.

headline.main: Genzyme's Drug for Rare Enzyme Deficiency Is Approved

docs.abstract: Genzyme wins federal approval to sell Myozyme, first drug for Pompe disease, rare inherited enzyme deficiency that destroys muscles and kills infants by their first birthday; officials say drug would cost about $200,000 to $300,000 per year, though significantly less for infants, and that it would provide drug free to those who cannot otherwise pay for it (M)
docs.snippet: The drug, Myozyme, is the fourth developed by Genzyme to treat a rare enzyme deficiency under incentives provided by the federal government.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two companies, UnitedHealth Group and Humana, have captured nearly half of the vast new market for prescription drug insurance under Medicare, according to new data issued Friday by the Bush administration. The figures provided a snapshot of a business that has been plagued by start-up problems, but could prove to be a fast-growing and profitable enterprise for insurers.

headline.main: In Scramble for New Medicare Business, a Few Insurers Grab the Most

docs.abstract: UnitedHealth Group and Humana have captured nearly half of vast new market for prescription drug insurance under Medicare, according to data issued by Bush administration; over 80 companies are offering more than 1,400 prescription drug plans around country, and 13.9 million enrollees are participating in plans; UnitedHealth, Humana and WellPoint account for 52 percent of enrollment; graph (M)
docs.snippet: Two companies have captured nearly half of the vast new market for prescription drug insurance under Medicare, according to new data.
